snippet: The amount, which requires Congressional approval, is less than what regional leaders had requested for Hurricane Sandy relief but more than the administration had estimated just a few days ago.
abstract: Pres Obama proposes a $60.4 billion emergency spending bill on to finance recovery efforts in areas pummeled by Hurricane Sandy, a sum that White House officials called a 'robust' investment in the region but that was far less than what the states had requested; spending plan would pay for most, but not all, of the $82 billion in damage identified by the governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

byline.original: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ and PETER BAKER

lead_paragraph: The amount, which requires Congressional approval, is less than what regional leaders had requested for Hurricane Sandy relief but more than the administration had estimated just a few days ago.

headline.main: Obama Asking Congress for $60.4 Billion to Help States Recover From Storm
headline.print_headline: Obama Asking Congress for $60.4 Billion to Help States Recover From Storm
